question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Instructions:

3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.

Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
Given the constraints and the defined logical symbols, we can symbolize the propositions as follows:

(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
This statement asserts that both p1 (Blue is a common color) and p2 (Yellow is a common color) are true at the same time. The logical connective that represents "and" is `&`.

Symbolization: `p1 & p2`

(2) Either `√3` or `5` is irrational.
This statement asserts that at least one of p3 (`√3` is irrational) and p4 (`5` is irrational) is true. The logical connective that represents "or" is `||`.

Symbolization: `p3 || p4`

(3) Exactly one of `√3` and `5` is irrational.
This statement is a bit more complex because it does not directly correspond to a single logical connective. It asserts that one of p3 and p4 is true and the other is false. We can represent this using `||` for "or" but also ensuring that they are not both true by negating their conjunction (`&`).

Symbolization: `(p3 & ~p4) || (~p3 & p4)`

Formatting the answers as requested:

```
[[p1 & p2]; [p3 || p4]; [(p3 & ~p4) || (~p3 & p4)]]
```

This directly translates the given propositions into the specified logical symbols, adhering to the rules provided.

### Question:
Given:
p1: 4 is even.
p2: 5 is odd.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd.
(2) If 4 is even, then 5 is even.
(3) Only 4 being even makes 5 even.
(4) 4 is even if and only if 5 is odd.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
Given the definitions and the propositions:

- p1: 4 is even.
- p2: 5 is odd.

We can symbolize the following propositions according to the specified logical rules and the provided definitions.

(1) Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd.
   This can be interpreted as "4 being even is a necessary condition for 5 being odd." This translates to "if 5 is odd, then 4 must be even," which is represented as p2 =::> p1.

(2) If 4 is even, then 5 is even.
   This directly translates to "if p1, then p2" (where p2 is '5 is even' here, not '5 is odd' as originally defined, so we'll adjust accordingly by negating p2 to represent '5 is even'), represented as p1 =::> ~p2.

(3) Only 4 being even makes 5 even.
   This suggests that 4 being even is both a necessary and sufficient condition for 5 being even. If we again adjust p2 to mean '5 is even' for this statement, it's equivalent to "4 is even if and only if 5 is even," represented as p1 = ~p2 (using the original p2 and negating it to represent '5 is even').

(4) 4 is even if and only if 5 is odd.
   This is a straightforward biconditional statement, represented as p1 = p2.

Formatting the answers as requested:

[[p2 =::> p1];[p1 =::> ~p2];[p1 = ~p2];[p1 = p2]]

This list represents the logical expressions for each of the four propositions, following the provided logical rules and symbols.

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formulas.
(1) ~(p1&p2&~p3)
(2) (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)
The answer format  is [[T:...;F:...];[T:...;F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[T:✓|✓|✓;F:x|x|x];[T:x|x|x,x|x|✓;F:✓|✓|✓]]

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To find the truth values (T) and falsity values (F) of the given formulas, we will follow the custom-defined rules and use the provided notation and symbols.

### Formula 1: ~(p1 &p2 &~p3 )

- **True Assignments (T)**: This formula is true when the negation of `(p1 &p2 &~p3 )` is true. This means `(p1 &p2 &~p3 )` must be false. For this to be false, at least one of `p1`, `p2`, or `~p3` must be false. Hence, `p3` must be true, and either `p1` or `p2` (or both) must be false.
  - `[T: x|x|✓, x|✓|✓, ✓|x|✓]`

- **False Assignments (F)**: This formula is false when `(p1 &p2 &~p3 )` is true. This means all of `p1`, `p2`, and `~p3` must be true, thereby `p3` must be false.
  - `[F: ✓|✓|x]`

### Formula 2: (~p1 &p2 )=::>(p1 =p3 )

- **True Assignments (T)**: For an implication to be true, either the antecedent (`~p1 &p2`) must be false, or the consequent (`p1 =p3`) must be true, or both. The consequent is true if `p1` and `p3` have the same truth value.
  - If `~p1 &p2` is false, we have two cases: `p1` is true or `p2` is false. Thus, `[T: ✓|x|✓, ✓|x|x, ✓|✓|✓, x|✓|x]`.
  - If `p1 =p3` is true, we have two cases: both are true or both are false, and `p2` can be either. Thus, `[T: ✓|✓|✓, ✓|x|x, x|✓|x, x|x|x]`.
  - Combining and removing duplicates, `[T: ✓|x|✓, ✓|x|x, ✓|✓|✓, x|✓|x, x|x|x]`.

- **False Assignments (F)**: The implication is false only when the antecedent is true and the consequent is false, i.e., `~p1 &p2` is true and `p1 =p3` is false. This means `p1` is false, `p2` is true, and `p1` and `p3` have different truth values.
  - `[F: x|✓|✓]`

### Final Answer
The truth values and falsity values of the given formulas, in the required format, are:

- Formula 1: `[[T: x|x|✓, x|✓|✓, ✓|x|✓]; [F: ✓|✓|x]]`
- Formula 2: `[[T: ✓|x|✓, ✓|x|x, ✓|✓|✓, x|✓|x, x|x|x]; [F: x|✓|✓]]`

Therefore, the combined answer is:
`[[T: x|x|✓, x|✓|✓, ✓|x|✓; T: ✓|x|✓, ✓|x|x, ✓|✓|✓, x|✓|x, x|x|x]]; [[F: ✓|✓|x; F: x|✓|✓]]`

However, to fit the specific format provided in the example, we should ensure each formula's results are contained within their own bracket pair, as follows:

`[[T: x|x|✓, x|✓|✓, ✓|x|✓]; [F: ✓|✓|x]]; [[T: ✓|x|✓, ✓|x|x, ✓|✓|✓, x|✓|x, x|x|x]; [F: x|✓|✓]]`

### Question:
Find the falsity values of the following formulas:
(1)~(~p1&p2)||~p3
(2)(~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)
(3)(p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)
The answer format is [[F:...];[F:...];[F:...]].If there are multiple values in F, they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[F:x|x|x];[F:✓|✓|✓];[F:x|x|x,✓|✓|✓]]

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To find the falsity values of the given formulas, we need to identify under which truth assignments the formulas evaluate to false. We will follow the given logical rules and notation.

### Formula 1: ~(~p1 & p2) || ~p3

This formula is false if and only if its negation is true. The negation of the formula is equivalently expressed as:

~(~(~p1 & p2) || ~p3) ≡ (~p1 & p2) & p3

So, the falsity values for Formula 1 are when:
- p1 is false (x),
- p2 is true (✓),
- p3 is true (✓).

Falsity value for Formula 1: [F: x|✓|✓]

### Formula 2: (~p2 || p3) & (p1 =::> p2)

This formula is false under two conditions: when (~p2 || p3) is false and when (p1 =::> p2) is false.

For (~p2 || p3) to be false, both ~p2 and p3 must be false, which means p2 must be true and p3 must be false.

For (p1 =::> p2) to be false, p1 must be true and p2 must be false.

However, these conditions contradict each other (p2 cannot be both false for the implication and true for the disjunction under the same assignment). Therefore, we need to find an assignment where the implication is false because the disjunction cannot be false when the implication is true (since p2 being true satisfies both).

So, the falsity values for Formula 2 are when:
- p1 is true (✓),
- p2 is false (x),
- p3 can be either true or false, but for the formula to be false, it must align with the condition that ~p2 || p3 is true, which it will be when p3 is true, but since p2 is false, the formula is still false due to the implication being false.

However, the analysis for the disjunction was overly constrained; the correct interpretation is that for the formula to be false, the implication must be false (since the disjunction alone cannot make the entire formula false given the analysis above), and the disjunction's truth value is irrelevant because it does not affect the overall falsity when the implication is false. Thus, we correct the falsity values for Formula 2:

Falsity value for Formula 2: [F: ✓|x|x] (p1 true, p2 false, p3 either true or false)

### Formula 3: (p1 =::> p2) & (~(p1 & p3) || p1)

The formula is false if any part is false. (~(p1 & p3) || p1) is always true when p1 is true (since it's a part of the OR condition), so for the formula to be false, (p1 =::> p2) must be false. This occurs when p1 is true, and p2 is false.

For the second part of the formula, (~(p1 & p3) || p1), to not affect the falsity, p1 being true suffices, regardless of p3. However, we want the specific case where the entire formula is false, which we've established is when p1 is true and p2 is false.

Falsity value for Formula 3: [F: ✓|x|x] (p1 true, p2 false, p3 either true or false)

### Final Answer:

Given the falsity values for each formula, the answer format [[F:...];[F:...];[F:...]] with falsity values separated by commas if there are multiple, we have:

[[F: x|✓|✓]; [F: ✓|x|x]; [F: ✓|x|x]]

This means that for Formula 1, it is false under the assignment [F: x|✓|✓], and for Formulas 2 and 3, they are false under the assignment [F: ✓|x|x], with p3 being either true or false in both cases without affecting the falsity of the formulas.

### Question:
Determine whether the following formula is:
A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

(1) p1=::>(p1||p2||p3)
(2) (p1=::>~p1)=::>~p2

Provide the answer as a single letter.
Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.
Eventually the entire answer should be formatted like [[A];[A]].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To determine whether each formula is a Truth Formula, a Falsehood Formula, or Neither, let's analyze each formula step by step according to the given logical rules and definitions.

(1) p1 =::>(p1 ||p2 ||p3 )

This formula states "if p1, then (p1 or p2 or p3)." For the implication to be false, we need a case where the antecedent (p1) is true, and the consequent ((p1 || p2 || p3)) is false. However, because the consequent includes p1 itself, if p1 is true, the consequent will also be true. Therefore, there is no way to make this implication false because there is no truth assignment that can make p1 true without also making the consequent true. Hence, this formula is a Truth Formula.

(2) (p1 =::>~p1 )=::>~p2

This formula can be simplified by analyzing the implication inside the parentheses first. The formula (p1 =::>~p1 ) can never be false because an implication is only false when the antecedent is true and the consequent is false. However, if p1 is true, ~p1 is false, so (p1 =::>~p1 ) is false in this case. But, if p1 is false, ~p1 is true, making the implication true. Thus, (p1 =::>~p1 ) is always true when p1 is false and can only be false when p1 is true. Given this, the outer implication, being true when its antecedent is false, means that the entire formula is true as long as ~p2 is true. Since the truth of p2 does not affect the truth of (p1 =::>~p1 ), the formula is true under all assignments to p2. Therefore, this formula is a Truth Formula.

Based on the analysis:

(1) is a Truth Formula, so the answer is A.
(2) is also a Truth Formula, so the answer is A.

The final answer formatted as required is: [[A];[A]].

Therefore, the answer is [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine whether each formula is a Truth Formula, Falsehood Formula, or Neither, let's analyze them step by step:

1. **~(p1 =::> p2) & p2**

   - The formula **~(p1 =::> p2)** is true if **p1 =::> p2** is false. The only case when **p1 =::> p2** is false is when p1 is true and p2 is false (✓|x). So, **~(p1 =::> p2)** is true if p1 is true and p2 is false (✓|x) because this negates the condition for **p1 =::> p2** to be true.
   - However, when we add the second part, **& p2**, it requires p2 to be true. This creates a contradiction because the first part requires p2 to be false for the entire formula to be true. Therefore, there is no assignment that makes this formula true under all conditions.
   - Thus, it is impossible for this formula to be a Truth Formula. It also cannot be a Falsehood Formula because there exist assignments (like when p1 is false and p2 is true) that would make this formula true. Therefore, it is Neither.

2. **(p1 & p3) = (~p1 & ~p2)**

   - For the formula to be true, both sides of the equivalence must have the same truth value.
   - If p1 is true, then **~p1** is false, making the right side of the equation false, regardless of the value of p2. However, if p1 is true, and assuming p3 is also true, the left side would be true, creating a mismatch.
   - Similarly, if p1 is false, then **~p1** is true, but p3 could be either true or false, and p2 could be either true or false, so it's possible to construct scenarios where both sides do not match.
   - There is no combination of truth values for p1, p2, and p3 that would make both sides of the equation consistently have the same truth value for all possible assignments.
   - Therefore, this formula is not a Truth Formula. It also cannot be a Falsehood Formula because there exist assignments (e.g., p1, p2, and p3 all being false) that would make this formula true. Thus, it is Neither.

The answer, formatted as required, is:

```
[[C];[C]]
```

This indicates that both formulas are Neither a Truth Formula nor a Falsehood Formula.

Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Given that p1=::>(p1||p2) is a Truth Formula,
 ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 is a Falsehood Formula, 
determine the type of the following formulas:
(1) (p1=::>(p1||p2))&(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)
(2) (p1=::>(p1||p2))||(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

Provide the answer as a single letter.
Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.
Eventually the entire answer should be formatted like [[A];[A]].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
Given the information:

1. `p1 =::> (p1 || p2)` is a Truth Formula.
2. `~(p1 =::> p2) & p2` is a Falsehood Formula.

We are asked to determine the type of the following formulas:

(1) `(p1 =::> (p1 || p2)) & (~(p1 =::> p2) & p2)`
(2) `(p1 =::> (p1 || p2)) || (~(p1 =::> p2) & p2)`

Let's analyze each one according to the provided logical rules:

### (1) `(p1 =::> (p1 || p2)) & (~(p1 =::> p2) & p2)`

This formula is a conjunction (`&`) of two formulas: the first part (`p1 =::> (p1 || p2)`) is a Truth Formula as given, and the second part (`~(p1 =::> p2) & p2`) is a Falsehood Formula as given. Since `&` requires both formulas to be true for the compound formula to be true, and we know that the second part is always false, their conjunction (`&`) can never be true for all assignments. Therefore, this compound formula is a Falsehood Formula.

### (2) `(p1 =::> (p1 || p2)) || (~(p1 =::> p2) & p2)`

This formula is a disjunction (`||`) of the same two formulas as in (1). The disjunction (`||`) of a Truth Formula and a Falsehood Formula will always be true, as a disjunction only requires at least one of the formulas to be true for the compound formula to be true. Since the first part is always true, the entire formula will also always be true for all assignments. Therefore, this compound formula is a Truth Formula.

### Answer:

Formatting the answer as requested, with `A` for Truth Formula, `B` for Falsehood Formula, and `C` for Neither:

- For (1): `[B]` (Falsehood Formula)
- For (2): `[A]` (Truth Formula)

Therefore, the complete answer is `[[B];[A]]`.

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To remove all occurrences of `>` in the expression `(p > q) > r`, we apply the equivalence rule (10) twice, which states that `A > B ::=:: !A | B`.

First, we apply rule (10) to `p > q`:
- `p > q` becomes `!p | q`

Then, we apply it again to `(p > q) > r`, substituting `!p | q` for `(p > q)`:
- `(!p | q) > r` becomes `!(!p | q) | r`

Now, we simplify `!(!p | q)`. According to rule (6), `!(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B`, so:
- `!(!p | q)` becomes `!!p & !q`

- `!!p` simplifies back to `p`

Thus, the overall expression `(p > q) > r` is transformed to:
- `!(!p | q) | r`
- `(!!p & !q) | r`
- `(p & !q) | r`

Formatted as required and removing unnecessary parentheses:
- `[p & !q | r]`

So, the equivalent expression without occurrences of `>` and formatted as `[[ ]]` is `[[p & !q | r]]`. - `!p|q|!r`

response:
To determine the validity of each equivalence according to the given 16 Basic Equivalences, let's analyze each separately and apply the logical transformations as necessary.

**1. ((p>q)&(p>r))::=::(p>(q|r))**

First, let's use the equivalence for implication (10 ): A > B ::=:: !A | B.

((p>q)&(p>r)) becomes (!p | q) & (!p | r) using this rule.

Now let's consider the distributive property (5 ): A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C). Applying this in reverse, we can rewrite (!p | q) & (!p | r) as !p | (q & r), because !p is common to both sides.

Now we need to check if (!p | (q & r)) is equivalent to (p > (q | r)). Using the implication rule again on the right side, we get !p | (q | r).

Comparing the two, we have:
- Left side transformed to: !p | (q & r)
- Right side transformed to: !p | (q | r)

These are not directly equivalent under the given rules, and there is no direct way to transform (q & r) into (q | r) using the distributive, commutative, or associative properties without additional operations that are not directly allowed by the provided rules. Therefore, the first equivalence is not valid under the given rules.

Finally, using the distributive property (5 ) in reverse, we can rewrite this as:
- A | !B & !A | B, which is equivalent to the right side of the original equivalence: (p|q)&!(p&q), by rearranging based on the commutative property (3 ) and the equivalence for negation of AND (6 ).

1. **(p⇓q)⇓r ::=:: p⇓(q⇓r)**

First, let's convert `⇓` to its equivalent form using the rules:

From rule (16), we know that `A ⇓ B ::=:: !A & !B`. Applying this to the given equivalence:

- LHS: `(p⇓q)⇓r` becomes `(!p & !q) ⇓ r` which then becomes `!(!p & !q) | !r` (applying rule (16) again). Using De Morgan's laws (rule (6)), this simplifies to `(!(!p) | !(!q)) | !r`, which further simplifies to `(p | q) | !r`.

- RHS: `p⇓(q⇓r)` becomes `p ⇓ (!q & !r)` which then becomes `!p | !(!q & !r)` (applying rule (16)). Again, using De Morgan's laws, this simplifies to `!p | (q | r)`.

Comparing the LHS and RHS, we see that they are not identical in the given form:

LHS: `(p | q) | !r`
RHS: `!p | (q | r)`

These do not match according to rule (3) since `p | q` is not the same as `!p | (q | r)`. Thus, the first equivalence is not valid.

2. **(p⇑q)⇑r ::=:: p⇑(q⇑r)**

Again, let's convert `⇑` to its equivalent form:

From rule (15), we know that `A ⇑ B ::=:: !A | !B`. Applying this to the given equivalence:

Comparing the LHS and RHS, we see that they are not identical in the given form:

First person: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Second person: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Third person: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."
Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou," 
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou." 
Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions. So, what would the statements of First person, Second person, and Third person be represented as?
Answers are formatted as [[ ];[ ];[ ]]. Each bracketed section should contain the corresponding logical expression for each individual statement.

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
Given the scenario and the symbolic representations provided, let's encode each person's statement using the logical operations defined:

1. First person: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
   This statement can be represented as "not p and q," which translates to `!p & q`.

2. Second person: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
   This statement can be represented as "not q and p," which translates to `!q & p`.

3. Third person: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.
   This statement implies he is not from Shanghai and not from Hangzhou, but since the options are limited to Suzhou, Shanghai, and Hangzhou, and given that exactly one of p, q, r must be true, this can be represented as "not q and not r," which translates to `!q & !r` or equivalently, as "p and not r," since one of p or q must be true, and p must be true if q and r are both false. So, for clarity and to align with the logical structure, we'll use `p & !r`.

Now, let's format these according to the instructions:

- First person's statement: `[!p & q]`
- Second person's statement: `[!q & p]`
- Third person's statement: `[p & !r]`

Thus, the final answer is formatted as:

`[[!p & q];[!q & p];[p & !r]]`

This representation adheres to the initial instructions and the defined logical operations, providing a clear symbolic representation of each person's statement.

rule_content:

response:
To answer the question, let's break down the conditions given:

1. **Basic Form**: A formula is a basic form if its principal disjunctive normal form includes \(m_0\), which corresponds to all literals being false (\(\neg p \wedge \neg q \wedge \neg r \wedge \neg s\) for a formula with 4 propositional variables \(p, q, r, s\)).

2. **All-Even Form**: A formula is an all-even form if all the indices \(i\) of the paired conjunctive terms included in its principal disjunctive normal form are even. These indices correspond to binary numbers (and thus hexadecimal numbers) that have an even number of bits set to 1.

Given these conditions, we need to find how many formulas with 4 propositional variables are both a basic form and an all-even form.

Since the formula must be a basic form, \(m_0\) must be included. Additionally, because it must be an all-even form, only even-indexed terms can be included besides \(m_0\). With 4 propositional variables, there are \(2^4 = 16\) possible terms, from \(m_0\) to \(m_f\) in hexadecimal. The even-indexed terms are \(m_0, m_2, m_4, m_6, m_8, m_{a}, m_{c}, m_{e}\).

However, since \(m_0\) must be included due to the basic form requirement, we only need to consider including even terms beyond \(m_0\). This means we have 7 even terms (excluding \(m_0\)) to potentially include in our formulas.

For each of these 7 even terms, we have two choices: include it or exclude it from the formula's principal disjunctive normal form, except we must include \(m_0\). Thus, we have \(2^7\) ways to form combinations of these terms, but this counts the case where only \(m_0\) is included multiple times. To correct for this, we subtract the multiplicity of counting the \(m_0\) case alone, which is 1.

So, the total number of formulas that satisfy both the basic form and all-even form conditions is:

title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

### Question:

and an empty set is denoted by ∅.

### Answer:
response:
To answer the question, let's follow the instructions and apply the resolution algorithm as described.

Given the conjunctive normal form: \((¬p ∨ q) ∧ (p ∨ q) ∧ (q)\)

1. **Initialization**:
   - \(S_0\) is initially empty. It is used to accumulate resolved clauses that don't lead to an empty clause.
   - \(S_2\) is initially empty. It will hold new clauses derived from resolving clauses in \(S_0\) and \(S_1\).
   - \(S_1\) is the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in the given conjunctive normal form. These are our starting points for resolution.

Before starting the resolution algorithm, we have:
- \(S_0 = \emptyset\)
- \(S_1 = \{(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), (q)\}\)
- \(S_2 = \emptyset\)

So initially, in the desired format, we have:
\[[\emptyset; \{(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), (q)\}; \emptyset]\]

Now, let's proceed with the first loop iteration, resolving clauses in \(S_0\) and \(S_1\). Since \(S_0\) is empty, we only need to consider the resolution of clauses within \(S_1\) itself.

2. **Resolve clauses in \(S_1\)**:
   - We have three clauses in \(S_1\). Let's denote them as \(C_1 = (¬p ∨ q)\), \(C_2 = (p ∨ q)\), and \(C_3 = (q)\).
   - Resolving \(C_1\) and \(C_2\) using the literal \(q\) and its complement \(q'\) (note that \(q' = q\) here since \(q\) is not negated):
     - \(C_1 = (¬p ∨ q)\)
     - \(C_2 = (p ∨ q')\) (since \(q\) can be treated as \(q'\) in this context for resolution)
     - \(C = dispel(C_1, C_2) = dispel((¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q')) = ¬p ∨ p = 1\) (not an empty clause because \(p\) and \(¬p\) resolve to \(1\), not \(0\))
   - Since \(C = 1\) is not an empty clause and is not in \(S_1\), we would add it to \(S_2\). However, \(1\) is not a clause we typically add because it is a tautology (always true), and adding it wouldn't contribute to finding an empty clause. Instead, we recognize that resolving \(C_1\) and \(C_2\) doesn't yield a useful clause for our purposes.
   - Resolving \(C_1\) and \(C_3\), or \(C_2\) and \(C_3\), doesn't change the clauses since \(C_3 = (q)\) doesn't offer a complementary literal to either \(C_1\) or \(C_2\).

After the first loop iteration, given that no new, non-tautological clauses were derived from resolving \(C_1\), \(C_2\), and \(C_3\) in a way that would contribute to finding an empty clause, \(S_2\) remains empty:
\[[\emptyset; \{(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), (q)\}; \emptyset]\]

However, if we were to explicitly note that we considered the resolution of \(C_1\) and \(C_2\) yielding a tautology, which is not added to \(S_2\), we could say that conceptually we observed \(1\), but \(S_2\) remains \(\emptyset\) for the next iteration:
\[[\emptyset; \{(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), (q)\}; \emptyset; 1]\]

But since \(1\) is not added to \(S_2\) and is noted here for observation only, the correct representation after the first loop, adhering strictly to the sets and notation requested, is:
\[[\emptyset; \{(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), (q)\}; \emptyset]\]

Note: The final \([1]\) in the last list I provided (\([\emptyset; \{(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), (q)\}; \emptyset; 1]\)) was an explanatory step to show the consideration of resolving \(C_1\) and \(C_2\) and recognizing it as a tautology, not part of the algorithm's output. The correct output format, strictly speaking, omits this step and focuses on the sets \(S_0\), \(S_1\), and \(S_2\), giving:
\[[\emptyset; \{(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), (q)\}; \emptyset]\]

This accurately reflects the state of the sets before and after the first loop iteration, without incorporating additional explanatory steps.

**Step 4: Check S2**
- `S2` is empty, so we add `S1` to `S0`, set `S1` to `S2` (which is empty), and clear `S2`. We then return to step 2.

- The algorithm iterated 2 cycles.

### Question:
For p∧(p∨q)∧(p∨¬q)∧(q∨¬r)∧(q∨r), 
what are S0, S1, and S2 before the second cycle of the resolution algorithm?
Provide the answers in the format [[];[];[]],
where sets are represented using {}, 
and an empty set is denoted by ∅.

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To apply the Resolution Algorithm as described, we first convert the given formula into conjunctive normal form (CNF) and then proceed with the resolution steps.

Given formula: \(p \wedge (p \vee q) \wedge (p \vee \neg q) \wedge (q \vee \neg r) \wedge (q \vee r)\)

This formula is already in CNF, with each clause being a simple disjunctive clause. Let's identify each clause:

1. \(p\)
2. \(p \vee q\)
3. \(p \vee \neg q\)
4. \(q \vee \neg r\)
5. \(q \vee r\)

### Initialization
According to the algorithm, we initialize three sets:

- \(S_0\) starts as an empty set.
- \(S_1\) is the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in the formula.
- \(S_2\) starts as an empty set.

So, before any resolution steps, we have:

\(S_0 = \emptyset\)

\(S_1 = \{p, p \vee q, p \vee \neg q, q \vee \neg r, q \vee r\}\)

\(S_2 = \emptyset\)

### First Cycle

#### Resolve clauses in \(S_0\) and \(S_1\)
Since \(S_0\) is empty, no resolution can be performed between \(S_0\) and \(S_1\). Thus, \(S_2\) remains empty at this stage.

#### Resolve clauses in \(S_1\)
Now, we look for pairs of clauses in \(S_1\) that can be resolved according to the rule:

- No resolution between \(p\) and any other clause since it's a unit clause.
- Resolving \(p \vee q\) with \(p \vee \neg q\) results in \(p\), which is already in \(S_1\), so this adds nothing new to \(S_2\).
- Resolving \(p \vee \neg q\) with \(q \vee \neg r\) results in \(p \vee \neg r\), which is not in \(S_1\) or \(S_2\), so it gets added to \(S_2\).
- Resolving \(p \vee q\) with \(q \vee r\) results in \(p \vee r\), which is not in \(S_1\) or \(S_2\), so it gets added to \(S_2\).
- Resolving \(p \vee \neg q\) with \(q \vee r\) results in \(p \vee r\), which is already being added to \(S_2\).
- No resolution between \(q \vee \neg r\) and \(q \vee r\) since the resulting \(q\) is subsumed by existing clauses.

After the first cycle, we have:

\(S_0 = \emptyset\)

\(S_1 = \{p, p \vee q, p \vee \neg q, q \vee \neg r, q \vee r\}\)

\(S_2 = \{p \vee \neg r, p \vee r\}\)

### Before the Second Cycle
Before the second cycle, we are asked to update \(S_0\) and \(S_1\) according to the algorithm. We add \(S_1\) to \(S_0\) and replace \(S_1\) with \(S_2\), then clear \(S_2\). Thus, we have:

\(S_0 = \{p, p \vee q, p \vee \neg q, q \vee \neg r, q \vee r\}\)

\(S_1 = \{p \vee \neg r, p \vee r\}\)

\(S_2 = \emptyset\)

Therefore, the state before the second cycle of the resolution algorithm is:

\[[\{p, p \vee q, p \vee \neg q, q \vee \neg r, q \vee r\}; \{p \vee \neg r, p \vee r\}; \emptyset]\]

Using the requested notation, this is:

\[[\{p, p \vee q, p \vee \neg q, q \vee \neg r, q \vee r\}; \{p \vee \neg r, p \vee r\}; \{\}]\]

### Answer:
response:
To apply the Resolution Algorithm to the given conjunctive normal form \((p \vee q) \wedge (p \vee \neg q) \wedge (\neg p \vee r)\), we first identify the simple disjunctive clauses in the formula, which are:

- \(C1: p \vee q\)
- \(C2: p \vee \neg q\)
- \(C3: \neg p \vee r\)

We then follow the steps of the Resolution Algorithm:

1. **Initialization:**
   - \(S0\) is empty.
   - \(S1 = \{C1, C2, C3\}\)
   - \(S2\) is empty.

2. **Resolve clauses in \(S0\) and \(S1\):**
   - Since \(S0\) is empty, there's nothing to resolve at this stage.

3. **Resolve clauses in \(S1\):**
   - Resolving \(C1\) and \(C2\) gives us:
     - \(C = \text{dispel}(C1, C2) = p \vee (\neg q \vee q) = p\) (since \(q \vee \neg q\) is a tautology and thus can be removed)
     - \(C\) is not in \(S0\) or \(S1\), so add \(C\) to \(S2\). Now \(S2 = \{p\}\).
   - Resolving \(C1\) and \(C3\) does not yield a resolvent because they do not contain complementary literals.

   - \(S2\) is not empty, so add \(S1\) to \(S0\), set \(S1\) to \(S2\), and clear \(S2\).
   - \(S0 = \{C1, C2, C3\}\), \(S1 = \{p\}\), \(S2 = \{\}\)

- Resolving \(p\) (former \(S1\)) with \(C1\) or \(C2\) doesn't add anything new to \(S2\), as \(p\) is already accounted for.
- Resolving \(p\) with \(C3\):

   - \(S2\) is not empty, so the process repeats. However, since all possible resolutions have been performed without deriving an empty clause (0), the next iteration will not add anything new.

- Number of cycles: 2

title: Circuit Diagram
rule_content:
In a simple circuit diagram, logical operators "negation", "conjunction", and "disjunction" function similarly.
When there is one input it is recorded as "I", when there is more than 1 all inputs are represented in order as "I1, I2, ......".
If powered, represented as "+"; if not powered, represented as "-".
The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O". Hence, a circuit diagram can be depicted and described like a truth table.

When there is one input it is recorded as "I", when there is more than 1 all inputs are represented in order as "I1, I2, ......".
If powered, represented as "+"; if not powered, represented as "-".
The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O". Hence, a circuit diagram can be depicted and described like a truth table.

### Question:
Please provide a simple circuit diagram for a NOT gate, 
formatted as [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To represent a NOT gate, we consider a single input (I) that can be either powered (+) or not powered (-). The output (O) of the NOT gate is the opposite of the input. Therefore, if the input is powered, the output will not be powered, and vice versa.

The format requested is:
- First, list all possible inputs and their corresponding outputs.
- Second, specify the output when the circuit is powered (which, in this context, means when the NOT gate itself is powered, not the input being powered). A NOT gate always inverts its input, so the output state will depict this inversion of the input state.
- Third, specify the output when the circuit is not powered. For a NOT gate, if the circuit itself is not powered, there should be no output (or we could consider it defaulting to the unpowered state, depending on the interpretation; we'll assume the former for clarity).

Given the above, the simple circuit diagram for a NOT gate, formatted as requested, would be:

[[I, O]; [O when circuit is powered, O when circuit is not powered]]

- When I is + (powered), O is - (not powered).
- When I is - (not powered), O is + (powered).

Considering these rules, the formatted representation is:

[[+, -]; [-, +]]

However, noting the request for the output when the circuit is powered vs. not powered, if we treat the "circuit is powered" as referring to the gate itself being operational (as opposed to the input state), then both those states will match the input inversion since the NOT gate's operation depends on it being powered; if it's not powered, we'll consider the output undefined or erroneous, denoted here as "X" for clarity (though in digital circuits, this might be more formally described in terms of floating or high-impedance states). Thus:

[[I, O]; [O when circuit is powered, X (undefined) when circuit is not powered]]

Results in:

[[+, -], [-, X]]

This format captures the essence of a NOT gate's operation and the specified conditions.

response:

- The inputs are represented by "I1" and "I2" since we have two inputs for an OR gate.
- The output is represented by "O".
- The power status is represented by "+" when powered and "-" when not powered.
- The OR gate functions such that the output is powered ("+") if at least one of the inputs is powered, and the output is not powered ("-") only if both inputs are not powered.

   - `[I1 = -, I2 = +], O = +`

4. When both inputs are not powered ("-"):
   - `[I1 = -, I2 = -], O = -`

Formatting this according to the specified format:

```
[[I1 = +, I2 = +], O = +];
[[I1 = +, I2 = -], O = +];
[[I1 = -, I2 = +], O = +];

```

What is the simple circuit diagram corresponding to the logical expression (p∧q)∨(p∧r)?
Please provide the answer in the format [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To represent the logical expression `(p∧q)∨(p∧r)` in a simple circuit diagram format with inputs and outputs as specified, we first identify the inputs and the logical operations involved. The inputs are `p`, `q`, and `r`, and the operations are conjunction (`∧`) and disjunction (`∨`).

Given the format [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...], let's break down the expression:

1. For `p∧q` to be true, both `p` and `q` must be true (`+`). This corresponds to `I1` and `I2`.
2. For `p∧r` to be true, both `p` and `r` must be true. This also corresponds to `I1` (since `p` is common) and `I3`.
3. The disjunction (`∨`) of the two means that either one or both of the conjunctions (`p∧q` or `p∧r`) must be true for the output to be true.

Given the structure, the circuit requires three inputs (`I1`, `I2`, and `I3` representing `p`, `q`, and `r`, respectively), and it will output `O` based on the conditions of the logical expression `(p∧q)∨(p∧r)`.

In the format provided:

- When all inputs are powered (`+`), the output is powered (`+`), because both `p∧q` and `p∧r` are true.
- When only `p` and `q` are powered (`+`), the output is powered (`+`), because `p∧q` is true.
- When only `p` and `r` are powered (`+`), the output is powered (`+`), because `p∧r` is true.
- When `p` is not powered (`-`), regardless of the state of `q` and `r`, the output is not powered (`-`), because neither `p∧q` nor `p∧r` can be true.
- When `p` and `q` are not powered (`-`) and `r` is powered (`+`), the output is not powered (`-`), because `p∧q` is false and `p∧r` is false.
- When `p` and `r` are not powered (`-`) and `q` is powered (`+`), the output is not powered (`-`), because `p∧q` is false and `p∧r` is false.

Formatting this into the required structure:

```
[[I1, I2, I3, O]; [+++, +]; [++-, +]; [+-+, +]; [-++, -]; [--+, -]; [-+-, -]; [+--, -]; [---, -]]
```

This representation covers all possible states of the inputs (`I1`, `I2`, `I3`) and the output (`O`) based on the logical expression `(p∧q)∨(p∧r)`, adhering to the specified format and symbols.

with output O as "-", 
what are the corresponding inputs? 
Please provide multiple inputs that satisfy this condition in the format [[];[];…].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To solve this, we need to find all combinations of inputs \(p, q, r\) that make the given logical expression \((p \land q \land \lnot r) \lor (\lnot p \land q) \lor (p \lor r)\) false (since the output \(O\) is "-", indicating the circuit is not powered).

Given the expression, we can consider the following conditions for it to be false:

1. The sub-expression \((p \land q \land \lnot r)\) is false when at least one of \(p, q\) is false or \(r\) is true.
2. The sub-expression \((\lnot p \land q)\) is false when \(p\) is true or \(q\) is false.
3. The sub-expression \((p \lor r)\) is false only when both \(p\) and \(r\) are false.

For the entire expression to be false, at least one of these conditions must hold for each sub-expression, given they are joined with disjunctions (\(\lor\)).

Let's enumerate the possible input combinations that make the output \(O\) "-":

- If \(p\) is false and \(q\) is false, the expression is false regardless of \(r\) because both \((p \land q \land \lnot r)\) and \((\lnot p \land q)\) are false, and if \(p\) is false, \((p \lor r)\) requires \(r\) to be true, which also doesn't affect \((\lnot p \land q)\) being false. This gives us \([\text{-}, \text{-}, \text{+}]\), where \(r\) can be either \(+\) or \(-\) since it doesn't affect the outcome anymore.
- If \(p\) is true and \(r\) is true, the expression is false because \((\lnot p \land q)\) is false regardless of \(q\), and \((p \land q \land \lnot r)\) is false because \(r\) is true. This gives us \([\text{+}, \text{-}, \text{+}]\) and \([\text{+}, \text{+}, \text{+}]\), covering the possibilities for \(q\).
- If \(q\) is false, both \((p \land q \land \lnot r)\) and \((\lnot p \land q)\) are false regardless of \(p\) and \(r\), giving us \([\text{-}, \text{-}, \text{-}]\) and \([\text{+}, \text{-}, \text{-}]\).

Compiling these into the requested format, we have:

```
[[-,-,+], [-,-,-], [+,+,-], [+,-,+], [+,-,-]]
```

These are the input combinations that would result in the output \(O\) being "-" according to the given logical expression and the defined circuit logic.

question:
In first-order logic, symbolize the following propositions using 0-ary predicates:
(1) Only 2 is a prime number, 4 is a composite number.
(2) If 5 is greater than 4, then 4 is greater than 6.

For (1), define a unary predicate F(x): x is a prime number. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

For (2), define a binary predicate G(x, y): x > y. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].
needle: Implication: Use ⇒

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.
Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |

response:

Putting these symbolizations into the requested format:
[[F(2) & ∼F(4)]; [G(5, 4) ⇒ G(4, 6)]]

This format aligns with the instructions, providing the symbolizations for each proposition in a syntactically correct manner, given the constraints of using 0-ary predicates.

response:

3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

Given the predicates and their meanings:

- M(x): x is a human
- F(x): x has black hair (used in both (1) and (4) but with different meanings, so we'll adjust for clarity)
- G(x): x has been to the moon
- H(x): x has been to Jupiter
- F'(x): x studies in the United States (adjusted to F' to differentiate from the F used in (1))
- G'(x): x is Asian (adjusted to G' to differentiate from the G used in (2))

- G(y): y is a turtle

F(x): x is even,
G(x): x is prime,

Using 0-ary predicates, symbolize the following propositions:
(1) 2 is an even prime number.
(2) If 2 is prime, then 4 is not prime.
(3) Only 2 is prime, for 6 to be prime.
(4) Unless 6 is prime, 4 is prime.

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].
needle: Conjunction: Use &
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.
Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

### Question:
Given the domain of individuals as the set of natural numbers(N),
F(x): x is even,
G(x): x is prime,

Using 0-ary predicates, symbolize the following propositions:
(1) 2 is an even prime number.
(2) If 2 is prime, then 4 is not prime.
(3) Only 2 is prime, for 6 to be prime.
(4) Unless 6 is prime, 4 is prime.

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To symbolize the given propositions using the 0-ary predicates defined in the logic rule, we first convert each proposition into a logical form, then translate it into the specified symbolic notation.

1. 2 is an even prime number.
   - This is about a specific number having both properties F and G, so we use the predicate form for existence with both properties:
   - Symbolization: `[Ex(F(x) & G(x))]` with the understanding that x=2 in this context.

2. If 2 is prime, then 4 is not prime.
   - This is an implication where the antecedent is G(2) and the consequent is the negation of G(4).
   - Symbolization: `[G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4)]`

3. Only 2 is prime, for 6 to be prime.
   - This is a bit more complex. It suggests that if any number other than 2 is prime, then 6 cannot be prime. In other words, for 6 to be prime, it must be the case that 2 being prime is both necessary and sufficient. However, since 6 cannot actually be prime, this is a conditional statement about the necessity of 2 being prime and 6 being prime under an impossible condition. We'll symbolize it directly as:
   - Symbolization: `[∼Ex(G(x) & x≠2) ⇒ G(6)]` Note: This simplification might not directly use 0-ary predicates but captures the essence. To adhere strictly, we break it down, understanding that if 6 is not prime (which it isn't), then any number being prime while not being 2 implies a contradiction:
   - Refined Symbolization: `[Ay(G(y) ⇒ y=2) & ∼G(6)]` This conveys that for any number to be prime, it must be 2, and 6 is not prime, indirectly capturing the intended meaning.

4. Unless 6 is prime, 4 is prime.
   - This is a conditional where the consequent is G(4) and the antecedent is the negation of G(6). However, we want to express it without directly using the antecedent, reflecting the "unless" structure:
   - Symbolization: `[∼G(6) ⇒ G(4)]`

Given the need for 0-ary predicates, we replace variable instances with the specified constants where applicable. The final answers in the requested format, adhering strictly to 0-ary predicates, are:

[[Ex(F(x) & G(x))];[G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4)];[Ay(G(y) ⇒ y=2) & ∼G(6)];[∼G(6) ⇒ G(4)]]

This format ensures each proposition is encapsulated in its own predicate structure, with constant bindings reflecting the original numerical references. Note that the third proposition's symbolization required a slight reformulation to strictly adhere to the 0-ary predicate requirement while maintaining the original intent.

For absolute clarity and strict adherence to the requested format and 0-ary predicate logic:

1. `[Ex(F(2) & G(2))]`
2. `[G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4)]`
3. `[Ay(G(y) ⇒ y=2) & ∼G(6)]`
4. `[∼G(6) ⇒ G(4)]`

Thus, the final, formatted answer based on the 0-ary predicate structure is:

[[Ex(F(2) & G(2))];[G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4)];[Ay(G(y) ⇒ y=2) & ∼G(6)];[∼G(6) ⇒ G(4)]]

This formulation strictly uses 0-ary predicates, assuming that constants (e.g., 2, 4, 6) are treated as bound variables within predicates for the purpose of this exercise, ensuring the logical form reflects the original propositions accurately.

- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
- Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.

title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

response:

- Inspector A: "All individual businesses did not pay taxes." This is a universal negative proposition (E), since it uses a universal quantifier ("all") and a negative connective ("did not"), and can be abbreviated as SEP (where S = individual businesses, P = paying taxes).

- Inspector C: "Some individual businesses have paid taxes." This is a particular affirmative proposition (I), since it uses a particular quantifier ("some") and an affirmative connective ("have"), and can be abbreviated as SIP.

Now, we look at the relationships between these propositions as defined by the logic rule:

- * Relation: Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions. If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.

These fit the description of the * Relation, where the universal negative (E) proposition contradicts the particular affirmative (I) proposition. If one statement is true, the other must be false, and vice versa.

[[*]]

rule_content:
Method A
- Definition: Change the quality of the original proposition (affirmative to negative or negative to affirmative) and replace the predicate of the original proposition with its contrary.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All S is not non-P.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All S is non-P.
    3. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some S is not non-P.
    4. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some S is non-P.

Method B
- Definition: Exchange the positions of the subject and predicate of the original proposition to form a new proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All P is not S.
    2. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some P is S.

Method C
- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:

Symbols: Use # for necessity, $ for possibility, letters like p, q, r... for propositions, ! for negation, + for conjunction, - for disjunction, = for equivalence, and > for implication.

(1) * Relationship:

- Property: They cannot both be true or both be false.

(2) x Relationship:

- Property: They cannot both be true, but they can both be false.

- Property: They cannot both be false, but they can both be true.

(12) !$!p → !#!p
(13) #p → p
(14) #!p → !p
(15) p → $p
(16) !p → $!p

response:

This translates to a disjunction (either-or) statement about the proposition p ("there is life on Mars") and its negation ¬p ("there is no life on Mars"). So, symbolizing the statement within the given constraints and aiming for adherence to the provided modal logic rules, especially considering the necessity aspect and the disjunction, we can represent it as: [[#(p - ¬p)]].

- This is a conditional statement where if p ("Li Ming plays well") happens, then it is possible for q ("he wins the championship") to occur. This translates to p → $q.

1. The symbols are defined as follows: ¶ represents obligation modality, § represents permission modality, and ‽ represents prohibition modality.
2. The four types of normative propositions relationships are:

(1) * relationship:
- Propositional pairs: ¶p and §¬p; ‽p and §p
- Nature: Both cannot be true and cannot be false.

(2) x relationship:
- Propositional pairs: ¶p and ‽p
- Nature: Both cannot be true, but can both be false.

(3) @ relationship:
- Propositional pairs: §p and §¬p
- Nature: Both cannot be false, but can both be true.

(4) % relationship:
- **Propositional pairs**: ¶p and §p; ‽p and §¬p
- **Nature**: Both can be true, and both can be false.

3. Normative reasoning formulas
(1) ¶p←→¬§¬p
(2) ‽p←→¬§p
(3) §p←→¬‽p
(4) §¬p←→¬¶p
(5) ¶p→¬‽p
(6) ‽p→¬¶p
(7) ¬§p→§¬p
(8) ¬§¬p→§p
(9) ¶p→§p
(10) ‽p→§¬p
(11) ¬§p→¬¶p
(12) ¬§¬p→¬‽p

### Question:
According to Modal Reasoning Formula 10, what can be deduced from "loud noises are prohibited in the reading room"?

A:Disallow not making loud noises in the reading room.
B:Allow not making loud noises in the reading room.
C:Prohibit not making loud noises in the reading room.
D:Prohibit making loud noises in the reading room.

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B/C/D]].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To answer this question, let's first understand Modal Reasoning Formula 10:

(10) ‽p→§¬p

This formula states that if p is prohibited (‽p), then not making p is allowed (§¬p). In other words, if an action is prohibited, then the omission of that action is permitted.

Given the statement: "loud noises are prohibited in the reading room," we can symbolize this as:

‽loud noises in the reading room

Applying Modal Reasoning Formula 10 to this statement, we deduce that:

- If loud noises are prohibited, then not making loud noises is allowed.

Therefore, according to this reasoning, we can conclude that "not making loud noises in the reading room" is allowed. This corresponds to option B: "Allow not making loud noises in the reading room."

Thus, the answer is:

[[B]]

### Question:
Modal Reasoning Formula 7 conforms to what following what relationship?

A.* relationship 
B.x relationship 
C.@ relationship 
D.% relationship

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B/C/D]].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To determine which relationship Modal Reasoning Formula 7 (`¬§p→§¬p`) conforms to, we need to analyze the types of normative propositions and their relationships as defined by the logic rule.

Formula 7 (`¬§p→§¬p`) states that if it is not the case that ¬p is permitted, then ¬p is prohibited. This formula deals with permission modality (`§`) and its negation, which is related to prohibition modality (`‽`) through the logical equivalence `‽p←→¬§p` (from the given normative reasoning formulas).

Let's examine the relationships:

- * relationship involves pairs where both cannot be true and cannot be false. This does not directly apply to `¬§p` and `§¬p` because they are not a direct pair of permission and prohibition, or obligation and permission.

- x relationship involves pairs where both cannot be true but can be both false. This doesn't match the scenario where the negation of permission implies prohibition.

- @ relationship involves pairs where both can be true but cannot be false together. This doesn't fit either, as we are dealing with the negation of permission leading to prohibition.

- % relationship involves pairs where both can be true and both can be false. The formula `¬§p→§¬p` suggests that if p is not permitted, then not p is permitted, which aligns with the idea that both the original statement and its negation can hold under permission modality (or not), depending on the context. However, the formula specifically deals with a transition from not being permitted to being prohibited, not the co-existence of permission states.

Given the options and the specific nature of Formula 7, which essentially converts a lack of permission into a prohibition, we can infer it most closely resembles the * relationship in structure, due to the interplay of negation and direct contradiction in terms of permission and prohibition. Even though the * relationship is typically defined for specific pairs of obligation and permission or prohibition and permission, the logic behind Formula 7 shares a similar essence of mutual exclusivity derived from the negation of a modality leading to its opposite (in a broader sense, not fitting the exact definition but the underlying logic).

However, if we strictly adhere to the definitions provided and understand that the * relationship is about contraries (cannot both be true, cannot both be false), and considering the given formula `¬§p→§¬p` suggests a transition from a lack of permission to prohibition rather than a direct contradiction of truth values at the same time, the * relationship does not perfectly fit. The * relationship is more about direct contradiction (e.g., `¶p` and `§¬p` cannot both be true and cannot both be false), whereas Formula 7 involves an implication from a lack of permission to prohibition, which is more about an exclusivity of states in sequence rather than contradiction.

Given the underlying logic and the definitions provided, and to directly answer the question within the constraints given:

- Since Formula 7 does not directly fit the * relationship in the strict sense defined (though it captures a similar spirit of mutual exclusivity but in a different manner),
- It does not fit the x or @ relationships because it doesn't deal with the pairs specified by those relationships (e.g., an obligation and a prohibition, or two permissions),
- And it doesn't fit the % relationship because it's not about the compatibility of truth values of an obligation and permission or prohibition and lack of permission, both being true or false at the same time.

Upon re-evaluation, considering the definitions strictly and acknowledging the initial interpretation's oversight, Formula 7 (`¬§p→§¬p`) actually reflects the inherent dynamic of the * relationship in its essence. The formula captures the idea that if it is not the case that p is permitted, then it is obligatory that not p is permitted (though the formula technically uses prohibition, which is the negation of permission, thus closely related to obligation in this context), thereby aligning with the spirit of the * relationship, where both cannot be true and cannot be false in this specific modality transition context.

Correcting to adhere strictly to the definitions and noting the interpretation should focus on the transition type represented by the formula rather than the direct contradiction of truth values at a single instance, the answer is:

[A]

Thus, the correct output in the specified format is:

[[A]]

This choice reflects the closest match based on the logic and transitions represented by Formula 7, aligning with the structure and essence of the * relationship, even though the formula itself involves permission and its negation (prohibition) rather than an obligation or permission directly. The key here is the mutual exclusivity in the transition between permission states, which parallels the mutual exclusivity of truth values in the * relationship.

### Question:
Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Wang Qiang worked in Beijing for one year in the past.
(2) Lin Min has lived in Ningbo in the past.

Use p to represent the ordinary propositions.

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
To symbolize the given propositions using the provided time logic symbols and rules, we first define the ordinary propositions `p` as follows:

1. `p`: "Wang Qiang worked in Beijing."
2. `p`: "Lin Min has lived in Ningbo."

Given the description of the events:

1. "Wang Qiang worked in Beijing for one year in the past." This indicates a specific period in the past. Using the symbols provided, a past period is represented by `A`. Therefore, this proposition can be symbolized as `Ap`.

2. "Lin Min has lived in Ningbo in the past." This indicates a fact about the past without specifying a period or a point. The most appropriate symbol for a general past fact would be `H`. Therefore, this proposition can be symbolized as `Hp`.

Given the format `[[];[]]`, we insert the symbolized propositions:

```
[["Ap";"H¬p"],["Hp";"¬Ap"]]
[["Hp";"H¬p"],["¬Hp";"¬¬Ap"]]
```

However, based on the relationships and the specific propositions we derived:

1. For "Wang Qiang worked in Beijing for one year in the past," we have `Ap`. Its related pair based on the inverse relationship (7) is `¬Hp → H¬p`, but since we are focusing on the positive assertion, we keep `Ap`.

2. For "Lin Min has lived in Ningbo in the past," we have `Hp`. Its related pair based on the inverse relationship (8) is `¬H¬p → Hp`, but again, we keep `Hp` as it directly represents the given proposition.

Thus, the final symbolized propositions in the requested format, considering only the direct representations without their inverse counterparts (which were part of the incorrect interpretation above), are:

```
[[];[]]
```

This format doesn't directly apply to our single propositions without their inverses. However, interpreting the format to include both positive assertions and their logical pair (which we mistakenly did initially before correction), the correct representation that clarifies the direct assertions without inverses would be more accurately represented by omitting the empty slots and just stating the derived propositions:

```
["Ap";"Hp"]
```

But to strictly adhere to the initially interpreted format requirement (even though it complicates the clarity), we could present it as:

```
[[];["Ap"];[];["Hp"]]
```

This format is to satisfy the `[[];[]]` structure requirement, keeping in mind the initial misinterpretation that led to including inverses. The accurate representation without such inverses, focusing on clarity, would simply list the direct propositions derived:

```
["Ap";"Hp"]
```

This last representation is the clearest and most accurate according to the given propositions and the requested format, focusing on the direct assertions without unnecessary complexity.

The inference from "It is not the case that Old Zhao worked in Ningbo all the time in the past" (\(\neg H p\)) to "Old Zhao did not work in Ningbo at some point in the past" (\(A \neg p\)) corresponds to the principle that if it's not true that something held at every past point, then we can say there was a past period when it did not hold. ### Question:
If a proposition p is the consensus of the group G, 
but the individual Alice doubts this proposition, 
what logical expression can be written according to the definition of consensus?

Please give your answer in the format [[]].

Let's think step by step.

### Answer:
response:
Given the scenario, we are told that proposition `p` is the consensus of the group `G`, which means `p` is a common belief within `G`. According to the definition of Common Belief, this implies that for every member `i` of group `G`, `B_ip` holds.

However, we are also told that Alice, an individual, doubts this proposition. Let's denote Alice as `A`. The fact that Alice doubts `p` can be expressed as `H_Ap`. 

Given the axiom of doubt, `Introduction of Doubt`, which states `H_p → ¬B_p`, we can infer that Alice does not firmly believe in `p`, i.e., `¬B_Ap`.

Now, considering the logical expressions and the given scenario, if `p` is the consensus of the group `G` but Alice (who we can assume is a member of `G`) doubts `p`, we have a situation where:

- For every member `i` in `G` except Alice, `B_ip` is true.
- For Alice, `H_Ap` and `¬B_Ap` are true.

The logical expression that captures this scenario according to the definition of consensus and the provided axioms is:

`[∀i ∈ G, i ≠ A → B_ip] ∧ [H_Ap] ∧ [¬B_Ap]`

This expression states that for all members of group `G` other than Alice, the belief in proposition `p` holds, and for Alice, there is doubt in `p` and thus not a firm belief in `p`.

So, the answer in the requested format `[[]]` would be:

`[[∀i ∈ G, i ≠ A → B_ip], [H_Ap], [¬B_Ap]]`

This encapsulates the logical situation where `p` is the consensus in the group `G` but Alice, a member of `G`, harbors doubt about `p`, leading to her not firmly believing in `p`.

question:
If Alice is sure that the library is open today (proposition p), 
and she is sure that she is sure of this (according to the axiom of self-reflexivity), 
what logical expression is written?

Please give your answer in the format [[]].
needle: - Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.
